sect2.title: INTRODUCTION
sect2.para: Listeria and Erysipelothrix are genera of small, non-spore-forming, Gram-positive bacilli that include the opportunistic human pathogens Listeria monocytogenes and Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae. These hardy species are found worldwide and cause significant diseases in domestic farm animals in addition to humans. L. monocytogenes causes listeriosis, a primarily foodborne illness that can occur sporadically or in outbreaks linked to contaminated food products. Though L. monocytogenes infections in immunocompetent people generally manifest as mild gastroenteritis, listeriosis is a severe, invasive disease in susceptible populations, capable of causing fetal loss and death in neonates, pregnant women, older adults, and people with cell-mediated immunodeficiencies. L. monocytogenes is an uncommon cause of foodborne illness but a significant pathogen due to the impact and high mortality rate of listeriosis in vulnerable populations.

E. rhusiopathiae is a comparatively minor human pathogen and cause of zoonotic disease. Infections are rare and usually linked to occupational exposure to animals. This species is the causative agent of erysipeloid, which is localized cellulitis that develops following cutaneous inoculation of the organism, most often on the fingers and hands. Less frequently, E. rhusiopathiae can cause diffuse cutaneous disease and invasive infections, including bacteremia and endocarditis.

BothL. monocytogenes and E. rhusiopathiae exhibit intrinsic resistance to antibiotics used in the empiric treatment of severe infections. Accurate identification of these less commonly encountered Gram-positive bacilli in the clinical microbiology laboratory is necessary to ensure the selection of appropriate antibiotic therapy for patients with invasive infections.

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: Listeria belongs to the phylum Firmicutes, class Bacilli, order Bacillales, and family Listeriaceae. The phylum Firmicutes contains Gram-positive organisms defined by their low G+C DNA content. Other genera of the order Bacillales related to Listeria include Staphylococcus and Bacillus (1). Differences in 16S rRNA sequence and distinct branched-chain fatty acid profiles separate Listeria from the morphologically similar genus Lactobacillus (2).

Twenty-six species ofListeria have been described, which can be subdivided into two major groups based on genomic and phenotypic data: Listeria sensu stricto, comprising L. monocytogenes, L. innocua, L. ivanovii, L. seeligeri, L. marthii, L. welshimeri, L. farberi, L. immobilis, and L. cossartiae, and those species which belong to Listeria sensu lato (3–8). A complete listing of Listeria species is found in Table 1.

L. monocytogenes was the first species described in the genus and remains the species most frequently encountered as a cause of human infection. It was identified at Cambridge University in 1926 as the causative agent of an outbreak in laboratory animals, which were noted to have peripheral monocytosis, and named Bacterium monocytogenes (9). The genus was renamed Listerellahepatolytica and, finally, Listeria, in honor of Joseph Lister and his pioneering work in antiseptic practices (10). In recent years, the genus has expanded with new species identified through environmental sampling, none of them pathogenic.

sect1.title: Description of the Agent
sect1.para: Listeria species are Gram-positive, facultatively anaerobic, non-spore-forming rods (0.5 to 2 μm by 0.4 to 0.5 μm) occurring singly or in short chains (Fig. 1). Filamentous cells (6 to 20 μm) may be seen after extended incubation or with exposure to high osmolarity or extremes in pH (11, 12). Mycolic acids are not present, and branching is not observed. The optimal growth temperature is between 30 and 37°C, but the organism is notable for its ability to replicate within a wide temperature range (0 to 50°C). Growth is slower at 4°C, requiring several days for macroscopic colonies to appear on solid media.

Catalase is positive, with rare exceptions (13, 14). Oxidase and indole are negative. Esculin is hydrolyzed within a few hours. Urea and gelatin tests are negative, and no H2S is produced. Methyl red and Voges-Proskauer tests are positive for organisms of the Listeria sensu stricto group. Species within Listeria sensu stricto, except the newly described species L. immobilis, are motile with peritrichous flagella. Motility is temperature dependent, with a characteristic “tumbling motility” observed at 20 to 28°C that is greatly diminished at 37°C. Members of Listeria sensu lato, except L. grayi and L. costaricensis, are nonmotile.

sect1.title: Epidemiology and Transmission
sect1.para: AllListeria species can be found as saprophytes in the environment and can be isolated from soil, water, vegetation, and human-constructed surfaces (15–18). Most species are nonpathogenic, and L. monocytogenes accounts for nearly all infections attributed to the genus. Environmental exposure to L. monocytogenes can lead to clinical disease or asymptomatic carriage in birds, fish, crustaceans, and mammals, including humans (19–21). Ruminants are at particularly high risk of listeriosis, which can present as septicemia, encephalitis, or fetal loss (22). In both humans and animals, the primary mode of transmission for L. monocytogenes is ingestion. It is a potential contaminant of food products and food production facilities and equipment due to its ubiquity in the environment (23). Efforts to control the organism are impeded by its ability to multiply at refrigeration temperatures and to endure environmental insults, including drying, elevated osmotic pressure, and extremes in pH (24, 25). Studies have shown L. monocytogenes can be isolated from 3 to 7% of raw milk samples in the United States, making consumption of unpasteurized milk or milk products particularly risky (26). However, food products can be contaminated at different points during production, including after pasteurization. Listeriosis is primarily associated with ready-to-eat foods not cooked by the consumer, including a variety of processed meats and fruits and vegetables, in addition to dairy products.

L. monocytogenes can be transmitted vertically. Vertical transmission is most often transplacental, resulting from hematogenous spread of the organism and tropism for placental tissue (27). The source of neonatal listeriosis with an onset 7 or more days after birth is less clear, but may involve exposure during delivery (28). Health care-related transmission is also possible, and outbreaks of Listeria have been reported in neonatal wards (23, 29).

Between 2011 and 2021, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) reported 21 outbreaks of listeriosis. However, reportedListeria gastrointestinal infection remains uncommon, with an incidence of approximately 0.3 cases per 100,000 population—the incidence of Salmonella or Campylobacter infection is >50 times higher (30). Most cases of gastrointestinal listeriosis are self-limiting and cannot be diagnosed with techniques commonly used in clinical microbiology laboratories, so cases reported to public health authorities are likely artificially low. Despite its low prevalence, listeriosis is the third leading cause of death due to foodborne disease, and outbreaks are associated with significant loss of life. In the U.S., an outbreak of listeriosis from cantaloupes in 2011 resulted in 147 infections and 33 deaths (31). It was the second deadliest foodborne outbreak in the U.S. since the advent of modern tracing, surpassed only by a listeriosis outbreak in 1985 associated with queso fresco that killed 52 people (32). L. monocytogenes is similarly the cause of the deadliest foodborne outbreak globally in recent times. An outbreak that began in South Africa in 2017 linked to contaminated “polony,” an inexpensive form of processed meat, sickened 1,060 people and resulted in the loss of 216 lives (33).

Human infections due to otherListeria species are extremely rare. A small number of infections due to L. ivanovii have been reported (34–37). The mode of transmission is unclear in these cases, and most infections have occurred in immunocompromised hosts.

sect1.title: Clinical Significance
sect1.para: The clinical presentation of an individual exposed toListeria varies from asymptomatic to mild gastroenteritis to life-threatening illness, depending on a combination of factors that include bacterial virulence, inoculum size, and underlying host defenses (38). Bacteremia, central nervous system infections, and maternal-fetal infections are the most common manifestations of severe L. monocytogenes infections. The majority of nonpregnant patients who develop invasive listeriosis have one or more underlying immunosuppressive comorbidities, particularly impaired cell-mediated immunity (39).

Bacteremia is the most common manifestation of severe listeriosis and can lead to focal infection.L. monocytogenes can cross the blood-brain barrier, and neurolisteriosis is the second most common form of invasive disease (40). Neurolisteriosis presents as meningoencephalitis (84%), meningitis (13%), or, less commonly, a more localized central nervous system infection (39). Average incubation times are 2 days for bacteremia and 9 days for neurolisteriosis (41, 42). The prognosis of invasive listeriosis is grim, with a 3-month mortality rate of 46% in patients with bacteremia and 30% in patients with neurolisteriosis. Outcomes in pregnant women and neonates are also poor: while seldom associated with maternal mortality, nearly one-quarter of cases of listeriosis in pregnancy result in fetal loss or newborn death (39).

L. monocytogenes crosses the placental barrier and exhibits placental tropism (40). Pregnancy-associated cases of invasive listeriosis have a long average incubation period of 27.5 days and typically present with nonspecific obstetrical signs or fetal loss, although the disease is generally mild in the mother herself (42, 43). The majority (82%) of patients experience major pregnancy complications, including fetal loss, preterm delivery, and neonatal listeriosis (39). Neonatal listeriosis takes three forms: early-onset, late-onset, and, rarely, granulomatosis infantiseptica. Early-onset neonatal listeriosis is associated with preterm birth and presents within the first few days of life, commonly with acute respiratory distress and bacteremia or meningitis (28). The majority of cases of neonatal listeriosis are early-onset (27). Late-onset neonatal listeriosis occurs after day 7 of life and more commonly presents with meningitis (19). Granulomatosis infantiseptica is a rapidly fatal disseminated infection present at birth, characterized by widespread micro abscesses and granulomas of the liver, spleen, and sometimes skin (45).

SymptomaticL. monocytogenes infection in immunocompetent adults is typically a mild, self-limited febrile gastroenteritis. Gastrointestinal illness generally occurs following exposure to a high inoculum of the organism in contaminated food. Exposure to L. monocytogenes likely occurs regularly despite the rarity of reported disease. Symptoms, if present, arise approximately 24 hours after exposure and include fever, watery/non-bloody diarrhea, nausea, fatigue, headache, and pains in joints and muscles. Symptoms last an average of 2 days and typically resolve without treatment (38). After exposure, transient stool carriage of L. monocytogenes can occur in asymptomatic individuals and is notably more prevalent in patients receiving long-term treatment with gastric acid-suppressive medications (20, 38, 46). Sporadic cases of Listeria gastroenteritis are diagnosed infrequently outside of foodborne outbreaks but may occur more frequently in patients with underlying gastrointestinal disease (47). L. monocytogenes can be considered as a potential cause of febrile gastroenteritis in a patient, particularly when testing for more common stool pathogens is negative.

L. monocytogenes is a rare cause of a variety of other focal infections, such as endocarditis, septic arthritis, osteomyelitis, peritonitis, pneumonia, and urinary tract infections, typically through hematogenous spread (48–52). Rarely, primary cutaneous listeriosis may occur through direct inoculation of the skin (53, 54). As with infections of E. rhusiopathiae, most cases occur in individuals with occupational risks, such as veterinarians and farmers exposed to animal products of conception (53). These infections typically present with a papulopustular rash on the arms and hands, accompanied by fever, and are usually self-limited. Ocular infections are also possible through both direct inoculation and hematogenous spread (55).

L. monocytogenes is an intracellular pathogen capable of both surviving phagocytosis and promoting its own internalization into a variety of nonphagocytic host cells (40). Invasion of otherwise nonphagocytic cells is mediated by internalins, a family of bacterial surface proteins that promote receptor-mediated endocytosis. Each internalin binds to specific host cell receptors, which may partially explain the tropism of Listeria for placental tissue and ability to cross the blood-brain barrier (56–58). After entry into host cells, Listeria escapes the phagocytic vacuole using a combination of listeriolysin O, a pore-forming toxin, and phospholipase enzymes. Once in the cytoplasm, Listeria is notable for its ability to polymerize actin using the ActA protein, forming characteristic “actin comet” structures that propel the bacterium through the cell and allow spread directly to neighboring cells (59, 60). In this way, Listeria can disseminate through a host while evading the humoral immune response.

OtherListeria species, mainly L. ivanovii, are rarely associated with human disease. L. ivanovii shares some virulence factors with L. monocytogenes and is capable of intracellular survival and spread. It is pathogenic in animals, particularly ruminants, and has been reported sporadically as a cause of human infections (34, 36, 61). Case reports exist of human infections with other typically nonpathogenic Listeria species, including hemolytic strains of L. innocua (62, 63).

sect1.title: Collection, Transport, and Storage of Specimens
sect1.para: Selection of specimens for the detection of listeriosis will depend on clinical manifestations, and will most often be blood and/or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). In cases of localized disease, affected tissue should be submitted for culture. Testing of stool specimens is appropriate only for epidemiologic purposes. No special handling is required during collection, but clinical specimens should be processed as soon as possible or stored and transported at room temperature or 4°C for up to 48 h. AlthoughListeria may multiply at refrigeration temperature, this will not compromise the clinical utility of cultures from otherwise sterile sites.

sect1.title: Direct Examination
sect1.para: Direct Gram stain should be performed on CSF, positive blood culture broth, and tissue samples. Detection of small, Gram-positive, regular rods in CSF or positive blood cultures should raise suspicion forL. monocytogenes. Cells may be arranged in V forms or palisades like Corynebacterium species and be mistaken for skin microbiota. The detection of bacterial DNA in CSF through PCR amplification provides an identification significantly faster than culture. One commercial test, the FilmArray Meningitis/Encephalitis Panel (BioFire, Salt Lake City, UT), is available in the United States. The use of a laboratory-developed real-time PCR for this purpose has also been described (64). Multiple commercial assays, including the Verigene Gram-Positive Blood Culture Nucleic Acid Test (Luminex, Austin, TX), the ePlex Blood Culture Identification Gram-Positive Panel (GenMark, Carlsbad, CA), and the FilmArray Blood Culture Identification Panel 2 (Biofire, Salt Lake City, UT), can be used to identify L. monocytogenes directly from positive blood cultures.

Commercially available multiplex gastrointestinal pathogen panels do not includeListeria species, and there are no FDA-cleared methods for antigen detection from clinical specimens. In the public health setting, non-clinical commercial PCR kits are available to detect Listeria species from food, and the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Bacteriological Analytical Manual contains protocols for implementing a PCR test for Listeria in food items without the need for a specific kit (65). These assays are for epidemiologic purposes or food quality assurance only; food products are not appropriate samples to test for the clinical diagnosis of listeriosis in patients.

sect1.title: Isolation Procedures
sect1.para: Isolation ofListeria can be achieved from clinical specimens from normally sterile sites, including blood and CSF. Blood should be cultured using standard blood culture media incubated on a continuously monitored instrument. Clinical specimens or positive blood culture broth should be plated to sheep blood agar and incubated at 35 to 37°C in 5% CO2 for at least 48 h. Stool culture is not recommended for the diagnosis of Listeria gastroenteritis or invasive disease (66). The most common media used for stool culture in hospital-based laboratories do not reliably isolate Listeria, and individuals without disease may shed the bacteria, resulting in a low clinical sensitivity and specificity. As the bacteria are resistant to cold temperatures, cold enrichment is a potential approach for isolation from polymicrobial samples.

Food specimens, though not appropriate as clinical samples, may be cultured in the public health setting as part of outbreak investigations as well as for food quality assurance. When tested, food samples should be subject to enrichment culture using University of Vermont (UVM) or Fraser broth and then plated to selective media, the most common of which are lithium chloride-phenylethanol-moxalactam (LPM), Oxford, modified Oxford, and PALCAM agars. Specific protocols are available from the U.S. FDABacteriological and Analytical Manual, the U.S. Department of Agriculture, and the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) 11290 (65, 67, 68).

sect1.title: Identification
sect1.para: L. monocytogenes can be identified from clinical specimens based on a small number of morphologic and biochemical features. It grows well on sheep blood agar and, by 18 to 24 hours, produces gray-white colonies with a narrow zone of beta-hemolysis, similar in appearance to Streptococcus agalactiae. Beta-hemolysis directly under the colony may be appreciated more easily by moving the colony aside (Fig. 2a). The characteristic tumbling motility can be assessed with a wet mount. This is observed best from a culture incubated at room temperature for a few hours; the organism may appear nonmotile if motility is assessed shortly after a culture is removed from a 35°C incubator. Alternatively, semisolid motility agar stabbed and incubated overnight at room temperature will show a characteristic umbrella-shaped growth pattern (Fig. 3).

The Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) M35-A2 guideline states that the following features provide a presumptive identification ofL. monocytogenes: small Gram-positive bacilli, a narrow zone of beta-hemolysis, tumbling motility, and a positive catalase reaction; with a positive hippurate hydrolysis test providing confirmation (69). A positive catalase test differentiates L. monocytogenes from Streptococcus and beta-hemolytic Enterococcus species. The positive hippurate test excludes beta-hemolytic Streptococcus species, other than S. agalactiae, which is also hippurate positive.

Commercial biochemical test kits can also be used to identifyL. monocytogenes, including the VITEK 2 and API Coryne and Listeria (bioMérieux), the Remel Micro-ID Listeria (ThermoFisher Scientific, Waltham, MA), the MicroScan WalkAway (Beckman Coulter, Brea, CA), and the BD Phoenix and BBL Crystal Gram-Pos ID (BD, Franklin Lakes, NJ), which provide identification to the species level. The RapID CB Plus system (ThermoFisher Scientific) allows reliable identification of Listeria to the genus level (70, 71). Infrequent misidentification of L. monocytogenes as L. innocua has been reported with the VITEK 2 platform (72). If a result of a Listeria species other than L. monocytogenes is obtained from a clinical specimen, review of the phenotypic features of the isolate as described above can prevent a potential misidentification.

The differentiation of species within theListeria genus based on biochemical characteristics has become increasingly complex and will not be reviewed in full here. These characteristics are important for accurate identification in food science, but there are comparatively few Listeria species encountered in human clinical samples. The presence of beta-hemolysis differentiates L. monocytogenes from the most frequently isolated nonpathogenic species, L. innocua (Fig. 2b). However, other species, such as L. ivanovii and L. seeligeri, are also hemolytic, and rare hemolytic strains of L. innocua have been described (Fig. 2c). As such, hemolysis alone cannot discriminate between pathogenic and nonpathogenic species. The CAMP (Christie, Atkins, Munch-Petersen) test can provide some differentiation among hemolytic Listeria species and resolve indeterminate hemolysis patterns (Fig. 4). The test is performed by streaking a hemolytic Staphylococcus aureus strain and Rhodococcus equi on blood agar plates. Isolates are streaked at right angles to (but not touching) the two streaks. Hemolysis by L. monocytogenes and, to a lesser degree, L. seeligeri is enhanced in the vicinity of S. aureus, and hemolysis by L. ivanovii is enhanced in the vicinity of the R. equi streak. Phenotypic features of Listeria sensu stricto species likely to be helpful for identification in a clinical laboratory are provided in Table 2.

sect1.para: It is increasingly common to use matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight (MALDI-TOF) mass spectrometry (MS) for bacterial identification, includingListeria (73). The FDA-cleared MALDI Biotyper (Bruker Corporation, Billerica, MA) and VITEK MS (bioMérieux, Hazelwood, MO) databases both identify L. monocytogenes but do not have claims for other Listeria species.

sect1.title: Typing Systems
sect1.para: Typing ofL. monocytogenes is used for the detection and tracking of suspected outbreaks. Typing is neither required nor useful for routine testing of clinical isolates. Historically, strain typing was performed by serologic testing based on somatic (O) and flagellar (H) antigens. In total, there are 13 described serovars of L. monocytogenes (1/2a, 1/2b, 1/2c, 3a, 3b, 3c, 4a, 4ab, 4b/4bX, 4c, 4d, 4e, and 7), and most strains that cause sporadic infections or outbreaks belong to serotypes 1/2a, 1/2b, and 4b. Antigens are shared among L. monocytogenes, L. innocua, L. seeligeri, and L. welshimeri, so identification to the species level is important prior to typing. It has been suggested that rapid typing of L. monocytogenes may also be accomplished using MALDI-TOF MS, but this application requires further research (74).

Molecular methods such as PCR, pulsed-field gel electrophoresis (PFGE), multilocus variable-number tandem-repeat analysis (MLVA), and multilocus sequence typing (MLST) have also been applied in public health settings (75–79). However, whole-genome sequencing has become the de facto gold standard for establishing relatedness between isolates and has markedly increased the number of Listeria cases where a specific food source was identified (80–83).

sect1.title: Serologic Tests
sect1.para: There are no FDA-cleared serologic tests forListeria infection. Serologic testing for determining current or past infection or exposure is not recommended.

sect1.title: Antimicrobial Susceptibilities
sect1.para: Current guidelines for the performance and interpretation of antimicrobial susceptibility testing forL. monocytogenes are available in CLSI document M45 (84). There are no interpretive criteria for other Listeria species. Drugs appropriate for susceptibility testing are ampicillin, penicillin, meropenem, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Due to the lack of resistant strains, breakpoints exist for susceptible results only. CLSI guidelines support susceptibility testing in cases of severe disease, penicillin allergy, or suspected treatment failure. If an isolate shows nonsusceptibility, laboratory error should be suspected. Isolates that test repeatedly nonsusceptible should be tested in a reference laboratory. The European Committee on Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing (EUCAST) recommendations include breakpoints for erythromycin in addition to the drugs included in CLSI M45.

Ampicillin is the first-line therapy for listeriosis if tolerated by the patient (66, 85). In patients with penicillin allergies, trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole or meropenem are the recommended alternative agents (66, 85). The possibility of in vitro resistance of L. monocytogenes to ampicillin has been suggested. However, these studies used nonstandardized susceptibility testing methodologies and should be interpreted with caution (86–88). Aminoglycosides exhibit synergistic activity with aminopenicillins in vitro, and combination therapy has been recommended, especially in patients <1 month of age (85). However, in retrospective cohort studies of nonpregnant adults, the addition of gentamicin did not decrease listeriosis mortality (89–91).

L. monocytogenes is intrinsically resistant to cephalosporins, fosfomycin, and fusidic acid. Results for these agents may appear susceptible in vitro but are ineffective in vivo. Notably, cephalosporins, such as ceftriaxone, that are commonly used for empiric treatment for meningitis are not effective for L. monocytogenes.

sect1.title: Evaluation, Interpretation, and Reporting of Results
sect1.para: Direct observation of small, regular, Gram-positive bacilli in sterile body fluids raises suspicion for listeriosis, especially in at-risk individuals, and Gram stain results should be communicated promptly. Rapid identification may be achieved through FDA-cleared molecular diagnostics that identifyL. monocytogenes directly from CSF or positive blood culture broth.

The isolation ofL. monocytogenes from a sterile site is always significant. However, as L. monocytogenes is a pathogen of sheep, bacteria present in sheep blood can be a potential, albeit rare, source of contamination of the sheep blood agar used routinely in microbiology labs (92). Isolation of L. monocytogenes in the lab should be investigated if it occurs with increased frequency or unusual growth patterns (i.e., off the streak line), particularly when isolates are inconsistent with the clinical context. Detection of Listeria species in stool samples may represent colonization, and routine screening of stool samples for Listeria is not recommended.

Accurate and timely identification is critical, as the use of ceftriaxone as empiric therapy for meningitis is not efficacious forL. monocytogenes, though the organism is reliably susceptible to ampicillin. Antimicrobial susceptibility testing should be performed in cases of suspected treatment failures, severe disease, and patients with penicillin allergy.

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: Erysipelothrix belongs to the phylum Firmicutes, class Erysipelotrichia, order Erysipelotrichales, and family Erysipelotrichaceae. The genus Erysipelothrix contains five species: E. rhusiopathiae, E. tonsillarum, E. inopinata, E. larvae, and E. piscisicarius (93, 94). E. rhusiopathiae is the type species of the genus and the only species associated with human disease. At least 36 names were used in the literature to describe the organism between its first description by Koch in the 1870s and acceptance of the name E. rhusiopathiae in the 1960s (95, 96). Historically, Erysipelothrix was considered a close relative of Listeria, but data on cellular composition, genetic content, metabolic functions, and phenotypic characteristics do not support the relationship (97, 98).

sect1.title: Description of the Agent
sect1.para: Erysipelothrix species are nonmotile, non-spore-forming, non-acid-fast, Gram-positive bacilli that have varied morphology on Gram stain. They are facultatively anaerobic and catalase negative and ferment glucose weakly without the production of gas. E. rhusiopathiae is the only species encountered clinically. On Gram stain, bacteria may assume a range of morphologies from slender and short (0.2 to 0.4 μm by 0.8 to 2.5 μm), to coccobacillary, to long, nonbranching filaments (60 μm or longer). Individual cells may be straight or slightly curved and arranged singly, in short chains, or in “V” shapes. Though Gram positive, the organism may stain unevenly or Gram negative due to easy decolorization.

On solid media, colonies generally develop in 1 to 3 days, with pinpoint growth (<0.1 to 0.5 mm in diameter) at 24 hours. As colonies mature, two morphologies are possible: rough (R-form) and smooth (S-form). With the S-form, colonies are small (0.3 to 1.5 mm in diameter), convex, transparent with a smooth glistening surface, and circular with an entire edge. With the R-form, colonies are larger, flatter, and more opaque, with a matte, uneven surface, and have an irregular edge. The R-form is favored by growth at higher temperatures (37°C) and the S-form by growth at lower temperatures (30°C). On blood agar, colonies are frequently alpha-hemolytic after 48 hours of incubation. Bacteria from smooth colonies are typically small, straight, or slightly curved Gram-positive bacilli and may even appear coccobacillary. Long filaments predominate on Gram stain of rough colonies (97, 99). Appearance may also vary with specimen type in addition to the conditions of incubation. Of note, both forms may be present simultaneously, and intermediate forms also occur.

E. rhusiopathiae is negative for most biochemical tests. In addition to being catalase negative, the organism is oxidase negative, indole negative, methyl red negative, and Voges-Proskauer negative and does not hydrolyze esculin or urea. E. rhusiopathiae weakly ferments lactose, fructose, and galactose in addition to glucose. It is positive for pyrrolidonyl aminopeptidase (PYR) activity and can produce hydrogen sulfide (H2S) on TSI agar, which is particularly helpful for identification (97).

sect1.title: Epidemiology and Transmission
sect1.para: E. rhusiopathiae is distributed worldwide. It is ubiquitous in nature and remarkably stable under varying environmental conditions for a non-spore-forming bacterium (100). The organism is pathogenic or commensal in an array of hosts, including mammals, fish, reptiles, and insects (101). It is shed from both diseased and asymptomatic animals and can persist in the soil for weeks (102). It can also survive as a saprophyte in the exterior mucoid slime of fish (102). E. rhusiopathiae has a significant commercial impact as a pathogen of domestic livestock, with swine considered a major reservoir. Vaccination is widely used in swine and other farmed animals to control disease (103).

E. rhusiopathiae is communicable to humans through direct cutaneous exposure involving animals or contaminated organic matter, with abrasions or puncture wounds of the skin likely facilitating the entry of the organism. The risk for infection is directly linked to opportunity for exposure, and cases are often occupational, with fish handlers, butchers, slaughterhouse workers, farmers, and veterinarians at greatest risk (104). The association with exposure to aquatic or marine life is particularly strong; the term “whale finger” was used to describe infections that developed in whalers who sustained cuts to the fingers and hands while working (105). In modern times, the term “fish handler’s disease” is sometimes used but is not to be confused with “fish tank granuloma,” caused by Mycobacterium marinum. Exposures may occur through recreational activities, including the care of pet fish (106, 107). There are case reports of infections associated with dog and cat bites (108–110). However, not all cases of E. rhusiopathiae infection have a clear zoonotic exposure (111, 112).

sect1.title: Clinical Significance
sect1.para: E. rhusiopathiae infections in humans, though rare, have been recognized since the 1880s (113). The bacterium was established around the same time as the etiologic agent of swine erysipelas, a significant disease of pigs with characteristic diamond-shaped skin lesions that can result in chronic disease or sepsis with death or with fetal loss (114, 115). The term “erysipeloid,” for human infection, was coined to distinguish the infection from human erysipelas, which is generally caused by Streptococcus pyogenes.

Erysipeloid has an incubation period of 2 to 7 days. It is a subacute cellulitis at the site of inoculation, usually on the fingers or hand. The lesion is well-defined, raised, and violaceous, spreading peripherally as discoloration of the central area fades. Pain, which is often severe, as well as swelling of the involved area develops. Vesicles may form, but the lesion is not suppurative. Infections usually resolve without treatment in 3 to 4 weeks, but treatment is recommended to speed recovery (116). Clinically, erysipeloid may resemble staphylococcal or streptococcal cellulitis, but distinguishing features include a history of occupational exposure, lesions on the hands, violaceous color, absence of suppuration, disproportionate pain, and subacute course of disease (117, 118). Rarely, a diffuse cutaneous form of the disease may develop, in which the lesion progresses proximally from the site of inoculation or appears at remote areas (116). This form is often accompanied by fever, lymphadenitis, arthralgia, and myalgia (119).

Systemic infections withE. rhusiopathiae also occur. More than 100 cases of bacteremia have been described in the literature (118). Endocarditis is frequently reported, though it may be overrepresented as a complication due to a reporting bias towards severe disease (111, 112, 120). Less common manifestations of severe disease include meningitis, osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, abscesses, pneumonia, peritonitis, and endophthalmitis (121–133).

While the clinical manifestations ofE. rhusiopathiae are established, the determinants of pathogenesis in the organism are not yet fully understood (134–137). Virulence factors under investigation include SpaA (surface protective antigen) protein, neuraminidase, surface adhesion molecules, the presence of capsule, hemolysins, and hyaluronidase (136, 138–140).

sect1.title: Collection, Transport, and Storage of Specimens
sect1.para: Biopsy specimens from erysipeloid lesions are the best source for culturingE. rhusiopathiae. Care should be taken to cleanse and disinfect the skin before sampling, as E. rhusiopathiae is difficult to isolate from polymicrobial specimens due to its small colony size and slow growth rate. The organisms typically are located deep in the subcutaneous layer of the leading edge of the lesion; hence, a biopsy of the entire thickness of the dermis at the periphery of the lesion should be taken for Gram stain and culture. Swabs from the surface of the skin are not useful. In disseminated disease, the organism can be cultured from blood in standard blood culture bottles or from tissue biopsy or aspirates of the infected body site. Standard procedures should be followed for the transport and storage of specimens.

sect2.title: Direct Examination
sect2.para: Direct microscopy should be performed with tissues, body fluid, and positive blood cultures. However,E. rhusiopathiae is typically not apparent on direct Gram stains of tissues and body fluids, and its morphology is notably varied and not distinctive, ranging from almost coccoid to long, filamentous forms. The presence of both short and filamentous forms may give a false impression that more than one organism is present (99).

Where clinical suspicion is high, 16S rRNA PCR sequencing directly from primary samples may prove useful whenE. rhusiopathiae fails to grow in culture, which is likely to occur in samples collected following initiation of antibiotic therapy. Testing of surgically excised valvular tissue by this method has identified Erysipelothrix as the causative agent in cases of culture-negative endocarditis (141, 142). Although 16S sequencing is not sufficient for species discrimination within Erysipelothrix, E. rhusiopathiae is the only human pathogen in the genus (93, 143). Targeted molecular testing for E. rhusiopathiae is not available for clinical use in humans.

sect1.title: Isolation Procedures
sect1.para: Diagnosis ofE. rhusiopathiae infection is usually reliant on the isolation of the organism from a tissue biopsy, blood, or other sterile body fluid. Tissue or body fluid specimens should be processed and plated onto blood or chocolate agar, placed in tryptic soy, Schaedler, or thioglycolate broth, and incubated at 35 to 37°C aerobically or in 5% CO2 for 7 days. Inoculation of an enrichment broth significantly increases the detection rate. Blood from patients with bacteremia or endocarditis can be inoculated into commercial blood culture bottles.

sect1.title: Identification
sect1.para: As the Gram stain is highly variable and the organism is infrequently encountered,E. rhusiopathiae may be mistaken initially for other Gram-positive bacilli, including components of normal skin microbiota such as Corynebacterium, Gram-positive cocci, or even Gram-negative bacilli.

Key physical and biochemical characteristics for identification are that the organism is typically alpha-hemolytic, nonmotile, catalase negative, PYR positive, and capable of producing H2S on TSI agar (Fig. 5). The organism may also form a “test-tube brush” or “pipe cleaner” appearance in gelatin stab cultures (144). A negative catalase reaction differentiates E. rhusiopathiae from Corynebacterium and Listeria species, and the production of H2S on TSI agar differentiates it from Lactobacillus species, which are also catalase-negative rods. More coccobacillary forms of E. rhusiopathiae could be mistaken for Enterococcus species, which are also catalase negative and PYR positive (99). Again, the production of H2S serves as a distinguishing characteristic.

The VITEK 2 and BD Phoenix automated identification systems can identify E.rhusiopathiae; however, the organism is not included in the database for the MicroScan WalkAway system. The API Coryne and Strep systems (bioMérieux) can also be used. E. rhusiopathiae can be identified by MALDI-TOF MS. Though not present in the FDA-cleared databases with the MALDI Biotyper or VITEK MS systems, E. rhusiopathiae is included in the RUO library for both platforms.

sect1.title: Typing Systems
sect1.para: Historically,Erysipelothrix isolates have been divided into serovars based on antisera to peptidoglycan antigens. At least 28 serovars (including nontypable) are described, but these serovars are not species specific or phylogenetically informative (103). Serovars 1a, 1b, and 2 are most associated with disease in humans and wild and domestic animals (145). Current approaches for classifying Erysipelothrix isolates focus on molecular typing schema (103, 146, 147). Typing of Erysipelothrix is used for the analysis of outbreaks in farmed animals and other epidemiologic purposes but has little clinical relevance in humans.

sect1.title: Serologic Tests
sect1.para: Serologic tests for the detection of antibodies toE. rhusiopathiae in humans are not available.

sect1.title: Antimicrobial Susceptibilities
sect1.para: E. rhusiopathiae is highly susceptible to penicillins, and penicillin or ampicillin are drugs of choice for treatment (118, 148, 149). Other β-lactams have in vitro activity, and broad-spectrum cephalosporins have been used successfully for treatment as well (111, 112). Clindamycin, erythromycin, and fluoroquinolones have also shown clinical efficacy and are options for treatment in penicillin-allergic patients. Notably, E. rhusiopathiae is intrinsically resistant to vancomycin, which is often used empirically in the treatment of severe Gram-positive infections; accurate identification is critical for the selection of appropriate antibiotic therapy. In addition to vancomycin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and aminoglycosides are generally inactive against E. rhusiopathiae.

The CLSI guideline M45 provides interpretive breakpoints for broth microdilution testing with penicillin, ampicillin, cefepime, cefotaxime, ceftriaxone, imipenem, meropenem, erythromycin, ciprofloxacin, gatifloxacin, levofloxacin, and clindamycin (84). EUCAST breakpoints are not available for this organism. Resistance to clindamycin, erythromycin, and fluoroquinolones has been reported, and susceptibility testing is warranted if these drugs are considered for treatment (137, 149, 150). CLSI breakpoints for resistance exist only for erythromycin and clindamycin, and nonsusceptible results for other drugs should be investigated and confirmed. One unconfirmed case report of penicillin nonsusceptibility has been reported in the literature (151).

sect1.title: Evaluation, Interpretation, and Reporting of Results
sect1.para: Detection ofE. rhusiopathiae in clinical samples should always be reported. Although E. rhusiopathiae is easily mistaken for more commonly encountered bacteria, including normal skin microbiota, the presence of this organism is associated with disease and not contamination. Identification is essential to ensure adequate antimicrobial therapy for severe infections, as E. rhusiopathiae is intrinsically resistant to vancomycin. The ability of the organism to produce H2S is a key distinguishing characteristic when morphology and biochemical tests are used for identification. Accurate identification of E. rhusiopathiae can also be made by MALDI-TOF MS and some automated biochemical identification systems. Antimicrobial susceptibility testing is not routinely required, as E. rhusiopathiae is predictably susceptible to penicillin. However, susceptibility testing may be indicated for patients with a penicillin allergy.
